questions.title: Question 1
questions.question:
What is wrong with the following instruction?

lw $s0, $t0, 20($t1)
questions.answer: The lw instruction does not take 3 registers. Its format should be lw $s0, 20($t0).

questions.title: Question 2
questions.question:
How about this one?

lw $k1, 15($s0)
questions.answer: The k registers are reserved for the OS kernel and should not be tampered with.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.question: Consider a 32 bit binary number stored in register $s0. Isolate bits 16 through 25 (i.e., keep bits 16 through 25 unchanged, but turn all other bits into zero) in four or less MIPS commands. Please store the result in $s0. Be sure that the bits end up in their original location.
questions.answer:
There are multiple possible answers, but here is one of them:

addi $s1, $s1, 1023
srl $s1, $s1, 16
and $s0, $s1, $s0
sll $s1, $s1, 16

Here's a different approach:

srl $s1, $s1, 16
andi $s0, $s0, 1023
sll $s1, $s1, 16

questions.title: Question 4
questions.question:
Translate the following C code statements into as few lines of assembly as possible (assume d is $s3, e is $s4, and Z's base address is in $s7):

d = e + Z[8];
questions.answer:
lw $t0, 32($s7)
add $s3, $s4, $t0

questions.title: Question 5
questions.question:
What MIPS instructions correspond with this C arithmetic:

a = (17 * b) + (c / 2)
questions.answer:
sll $t0, $s1, 4
add $t0, $t0, $s1
srl $s2, $s2, 1
add $s0, $s1, $s2

questions.title: Question 6
questions.question: Isolate bits 22 through 24 (inclusive) using only SLL and SRL.
questions.answer:
srl $t0, $t0, 22
sll $t0, $t0, 29
srl $t0, $t0, 7

questions.title: Question 7
questions.question: Access array position A[13] (assuming base address is in s0).
questions.answer: lw $t0, 52($s0)

questions.title: Question 8
questions.question:
For what range of values is the following MIPS arithmetic valid (i.e. no overflow, underflow, etc.), assuming that we are working with a signed number.

sll $s0, $s0, 16
questions.answer: We must have any value which cannot overflow into the most significant bit (which would flip the sign of the number). Therefore, any number which is 32767 (0111 1111 1111 1111) or less will not overflow.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.question: Can unconditional branches compare numbers before branching?
questions.answer: No. Unconditional branches branch to a different section of the program no matter what, and they do not have register operands.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.question: Can conditional branches branch if x < y?
questions.answer: No. Conditional branches evaluate either == or !=.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.question: True or false: conditional branches take two register operands and a label to branch to.
questions.answer: This is true.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.question:
What are the MIPS instructions which correspond with this C statement? Assume that $s0 = a, $s1 = b, and $s2 = c.

if (a != b) {
c = 24;
}
questions.answer:
Here is a possible approach:

beq $s0, $s1, Branch
addi $s2, $zero, 24
Branch:

And the reason it is a beq and not bne is that this is the only particular case where the c = 24 will not be evaluated.

questions.title: Question 5
questions.question:
What is the issue with the below MIPS code?

addi $s0, $zero, 0
Loop:
addi $s0, $s0, 1
beq $s0, $zero, Exit
j Loop
Exit:
questions.answer: The problem is that this code will never actually exit the Loop (that is until $s0 eventually overflows, but that is not the desired behavior).

questions.title: Question 6
questions.question: Transfer the MIPS code from the previous statement into C code.
questions.answer:
This type of loop could almost be compared to a failed do while loop.

int a = 0;
do {
a++;
} while (a != 0);

Since the a++ occurs before the comparison, it will continue running infinitely (until overflow, etc.). Sometimes trying to translate a MIPS statement into C will help illuminate errors you can not immediately see.

questions.title: Question 7
questions.question:
What is the problem with the below MIPS loop?

addi $s1, $zero, 20
Loop:
beq $s0, $s1, Exit
addi $s1, $s1, 1
Exit:
questions.answer: There is no unconditional branch which actually forms the loop, so the code exits after one run-through.

questions.title: Question 8
questions.question:
Translate the following C loop into MIPS. Assume that $s0 = a, $s1 = b, and $s2 = c.

for (int a = 0; a != c; a++) {
b = c;
}
questions.answer:
Here is one possible way:

add $s0, $zero, $zero
Loop:
beq $s0, $s2, Exit
add $s1, $s2, $zero
addi $s0, $s0, 1
j Loop
Exit:

questions.title: Question 9
questions.question:
What is the issue with the below MIPS statement?

# Evaluate if a == c
beq #s0, #s2, Equal

# Do not equal stuff here
addi $s0, $s0, 12

# Do some cool stuff if equal
Equal:
subi $s0, $s2, 1
sll $s0, $s0, 1
questions.answer: The equal portion of the code will be executed no matter what because that block of code will eventually execute. We would fix this by adding an unconditional branch to go past the equal code if a and c are not equal.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.question: What is unique about the jal function (i.e. what makes it different from the jump instruction)?
questions.answer: The jal function sets the $ra and jumps to the procedure, while j (jump) will just unconditional branch and do nothing else.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.question: What does the jal function set the $ra register to?
questions.answer: It sets the $ra to the instruction (word) following the function call (PC+4).

questions.title: Question 3
questions.question: Why are some registers assumed to be preserved across function calls?
questions.answer: This is particularly important because it can help prevent fatal register overwrites. For example, if the main program is using register $s0 to hold an important user stored value, and function A overwrites it, then that will be lost when control is returned to main.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.question: If you need to “spill” registers in a function in order to leverage additional registers, which ones would you be spilling?
questions.answer: The $s0-$s7 registers would be spilled to the stack as needed.

questions.title: Question 5
questions.question: What does this spill look like (in MIPS)?
questions.answer:
Here is an example of “spilling” $s0.

addi $sp, $sp, -4
sw $s0, 0($sp)
# Manipulating s0 here...
lw $s0, 0($sp) # Restore s0.
addi $sp, $sp, 4 # Make sure to readjust $sp in the end.

questions.title: Question 6
questions.question: Which registers are not preserved across function calls?
questions.answer: $t0-$t9, $v0-$v1, $a0-$a3, and the $ra may have to be saved in the case of a nested function (it is a bit of a special case).

questions.title: Question 7
questions.question: Which way does the stack grow?
questions.answer: The stack is said to grow downward, but what this means is that its indexing starts high and is slowly decremented as more items are inserted. Remember that the stack is a LIFO structure as we learned in data structures, so functions should not be messing with the stack anywhere above the stack pointer.

questions.title: Question 8
questions.question: Why shouldn’t procedures have the ability to change the stack above the current stack pointer?
questions.answer: This would be a mistake because that memory was not stored by the procedure (callee), but rather by some higher level caller which will likely need the memory it has saved to the stack.

questions.title: Question 9
questions.question: Why is it so important to “release” memory from the stack once you are finished with it?
questions.answer: Take the example where a silly procedure decides to allocate memory to the stack and alter the stack pointer but not change the stack pointer back after it is done. The caller program then retrieves the two elements it saved to the stack before it called the procedure. It got the wrong items back!!

questions.title: Question 10
questions.question: When memory is “released” from the stack, do those memory locations get set back to the value of 0?
questions.answer: No, they do not. They will stay whatever values they were, and this means we must be especially careful! The same goes for registers — they will never get set back to zero unless you specify them to do so.

questions.title: Question 11
questions.question: Give an example of an arbitrary function call whose function uses both the $t0 and $s0 registers. You can assume that both the $t0 and $s0 registers are important to the main function.
questions.answer:
addi $sp, $sp, -4
sw $t0, 0($sp)
jal function
lw $t0, 0($sp)
addi $sp, $sp, 4
# End the program.
function:
 addi $sp, $sp, -4
 sw $s0, 0($sp)
 addi $s0, $zero, 20
 # more arbitrary stuff...
 lw $s0, 0($sp)
 addi $sp, $sp, 4
 jr $ra

questions.title: Question 12
questions.question:
What is wrong with the below function call?

addi $s0, $s0, 5 # Some really important s0 stuff.
jal function
function:
 addi $sp, $sp, -4
 sw $t0, 0($sp)
 andi $s0, $s0, 0
 jr $ra
questions.answer: There are multiple problems here! For one, the $sp is never readjusted at the end of the function. Additionally, function saved $t0, which it didn’t need to, and it should have saved $s0 instead since it changed $s0 (and the main program didn’t expect that!). One other thing to always look out for is that after jal function, the program runs into function again, and since $ra hasn’t changed, this function may loop forever.
